content:
Nice idea, but currently the test cases are not well-matched to the validators and the hardest edge cases only occur in Validators 3 and 4.

Validators 3 and 4 are the only tests that ensure clashers recognise that you can give change for $20 as either $10 + $5 or simply 3 x $5. I didn't think of this in my clash, but got 100% on test cases, so submitted it, but then got 85% on Validators. In the end everyone failed besides a bot, so I came 2nd.

It's a pain to hide the toughest test cases in Validators, because then clashers don't have any way to debug the problem before submitting. If you get 100% on the tests, then you assume you've solved the problem and don't tend to spend time looking for edge cases you may have missed (especially in Fastest mode).

I recommend you swap Validator 3 with Test 3, and/or simply add some extra tests that cover this issue.

The result for

5
5 5 5 10 20

is not well defined, because nothing in the statement compels me to give back 5$ and 10$ instead of 3*5$.

I guess, implicitly expecting common sense doesnt make for clearcut problem statements.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Array
I took the liberty to disable reverse mode for this clash, because you really need to have access to the statement to be able to understand the problem.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It teaches loops, conditions and array management.
Nice puzzle, would be fun in reverse.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Short and fun puzzle for practicing loops and conditions
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
The example with not enough change, is clear but it would be great to have a simple working example or specify in output section that they are the numbers of bills you got in hands at the end.
Interesting idea!
Interesting puzzle!
Fun clash. I feel like this could also be a good reverse puzzle, especially If you add several more simple tests that will make it easier to understand what's going on without reading the statement.

Interesting puzzle, and good for CoC. Most of it is good, but the test cases are not matched with their validators. For example, both Test 1 and Val 1 should be "Out of change!" and have n = 3, both Test 2 and Val 2 should have the same n and have a successful yard sale (a Test 5/Val 5 might address n = 1), and both Test 3 and Val 3 would test that the solution code addresses two different ways to give change for a $20. 

I modified the third paragraph of the statement (among other minor edits) because it was missing something when I first read it.
As per contribution guidelines, binary output should be avoided (i.e. there are only two possible outputs, "true" or "false" in your case). Please revise the output requirements. Thanks.

I have made the necessary changes, please review.

Also, I couldn't find the contribution guidelines you were talking about would you mind giving me a link?

Thank you for your feedback and edits. However, I think making both n and the output the same for tests and validators makes it easier to hardcode solutions. For example, if you know that every test that expects "Not enough change!" will have the validator as  "Not enough change!" and n is the same for both test and validator then you could just explicitly insert the condition if n==3:print("Not enough change!") and it would work. Therefore, I think it's best to have at least one of n or the output different for tests and validators.
Thanks for your feedback, I will try to come up with some clear test cases to make it work for reverse mode.
Thanks for your feedback. I have added another example for making the output format clear. Hope that helps. Feel free to edit the statement if you think more changes/examples are required.
Man, you really want to watch the world burn

I don't get your point, for the case you mentioned the answer would be 1 0 1. There can be no other answer since the data is processed in a queue, i.e. you have to give a $5 and $10 bill for $20 as you wouldn't have 3 $5 bills by the time you receive the $10 bill because you have to give back a $5 bill.

Yeah, the example was badly chosen.

6
5 5 5 5 10 20

is a better one.

This allows for 2 0 1 and 0 1 1 as possible answers.

Ahh I see, that is a valid point. Initially, the output value was boolean so this problem didn't arise, after I changed the output to the number of bills I didn't consider this. To resolve this maybe I could add a note saying that the problem should be solved using a greedy approach. What do you think?
I added reverse mode and some test cases to go along with it. I would appreciate any more test case suggestions if you think the ones I added are not enough.
Here you are: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/contribution-guidelines
